title.value: A three-state coupled Markov switching model for COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on hospital admissions
title.justification: Title as mentioned in the provided text.
title.quote: A three-state coupled Markov switching model for COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on hospital admissions

extractions.description: This paper proposes a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks based on hospital admissions in Quebec. The model accounts for disease states of absence, endemic, and outbreak, and incorporates factors like covariates and geographical spread. The paper demonstrates that mobility and the introduction of new variants are strong factors in outbreak emergence and persistence.

type.justification: The paper deals with the analysis of COVID-19 outbreak data and model performance, which involves empirical work.
type.quote: We develop a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on admissions in the 30 largest hospitals.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on the epidemiological analysis of COVID-19 outbreaks.
name.quote: Many methods have been proposed for modeling infectious disease counts in space and time, a subject that has gained increased attention in recent years partly due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

name.justification: The paper employs Bayesian methods to build and validate the model.
name.quote: We develop a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on admissions in the 30 largest hospitals.

name.justification: The study utilizes a Markov switching model to analyze disease states and transitions.
name.quote: In this paper we take a Markov switching approach to modeling the occurrence of the outbreak periods.

name.justification: The model incorporates spatial and temporal factors to understand the spread of COVID-19 outbreaks.
name.quote: We develop a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on admissions in the 30 largest hospitals.

name.value: Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model
name.justification: This is the primary model proposed by the paper for analyzing COVID-19 outbreaks.
name.quote: We develop a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on admissions in the 30 largest hospitals.

is_contributed.justification: The CMSNB(1,2,4) model is introduced and validated in the paper itself.
is_contributed.quote: We develop a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on admissions in the 30 largest hospitals.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed to analyze hospital admissions data and derive results.
is_executed.quote: To fit the CMSNB(1,2,4) model, we used our proposed hybrid Gibbs sampler from Section 3.

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared to non-coupled and endemic-epidemic models.
is_compared.quote: We also fit a model without neighboring outbreak indicators in the transition probabilities, that is, with Î±lk,p+1 = 0 for lk = 12, 21, 23, 33 in (4)-(5), which we will refer to as the Non-coupled Model. Additionally, we fit a two-state model without any absence or clone states, which we will refer to as the No Absence/Clone State Model.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is a new model developed in this particular paper, so it does not reference another paper for the model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We develop a Bayesian three-state coupled Markov switching model to analyze COVID-19 outbreaks across Quebec based on admissions in the 30 largest hospitals.

name.value: COVID-19 hospital admissions data from Quebec
name.justification: The paper utilizes hospitalization data from the 30 largest hospitals in Quebec for model validation and analysis.
name.quote: In this paper we analyze weekly COVID-19 hospital admissions in the 30 largest hospitals in Quebec.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the data collected specifically for this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In this paper we analyze weekly COVID-19 hospital admissions in the 30 largest hospitals in Quebec.

name.justification: Google's retail and recreation mobility metrics are used as covariates in the model.
name.quote: We used the retail+recreation mobility metric which measures changes in visits to places like restaurants, cafes, shopping centers, museums, libraries, and movie theaters.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This mobility data is publicly available and utilized in the paper as a covariate.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Google LLC (2022) provides daily metrics that measure mobility as a percent change in the number of visits to certain venues, based on personal electronic devices, from days of the same weekday in January 2020.

name.justification: The Nimble R package was used to implement the custom samplers for the models.
name.quote: Our hybrid Gibbs sampler was implemented using the R package Nimble (de Valpine et al., 2017).

referenced_paper_title.value: Programming with models: Writing statistical algorithms for general model structures with NIMBLE
referenced_paper_title.justification: The package is directly referenced in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Our hybrid Gibbs sampler was implemented using the R package Nimble (de Valpine et al., 2017).
